samples.experiment_context: Effect of pH on MRR using CeO₂ abrasive slurry. Conditions: 70 ml/min flow rate, pH 7, 0.4% Vol H₂O₂, 20 kPa pressure.

spectroscopy_analysis.notes: Fig 5a: Ce³⁺ ions dominant. Lowest MRR for CeO₂ observed at this pH.

cmp_performance.equipment_model: PM5 auto-lap precision lapping/polishing machine (Logitech Co.)

samples.experiment_context: Effect of pH on MRR using CeO₂ abrasive slurry. Conditions: 70 ml/min flow rate, pH 9, 0.4% Vol H₂O₂, 20 kPa pressure.

samples.experiment_context: Effect of pH on MRR using CeO₂ abrasive slurry. Conditions: 70 ml/min flow rate, pH 10, 0.4% Vol H₂O₂, 20 kPa pressure.

spectroscopy_analysis.notes: Fig 5b: Ce³⁺ ions mainly exist. Highest MRR observed around this pH.

cmp_performance.equipment_model: PM5 auto-lap precision lapping/polishing machine (Logitech Co.)

samples.experiment_context: Effect of pH on MRR using CeO₂ abrasive slurry. Conditions: 70 ml/min flow rate, pH 11, 0.4% Vol H₂O₂, 20 kPa pressure.

spectroscopy_analysis.notes: Fig 5e: Increased pH reduces requirement to oxidize Ce³⁺, leading to more Ce⁴⁺, potentially decreasing MRR compared to pH 10 despite graph showing similar value.

cmp_performance.equipment_model: PM5 auto-lap precision lapping/polishing machine (Logitech Co.)
